title: Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infection (NSTI)
diagnosis_topic: Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infection (NSTI) – Sepsis & Source Control
setup_script: “A 57-year-old male with poorly controlled diabetes and chronic kidney disease presents to the emergency department with rapidly progressive pain, swelling, and erythema of his right thigh. He reports the symptoms began 24 hours ago but have worsened dramatically in the past 6 hours. He is febrile to 39.5°C, tachycardic to 135 bpm, hypotensive at 85/50 mmHg, and tachypneic at 28/min. On exam, his right thigh is erythematous with tense swelling, violaceous discoloration, crepitus, and exquisite tenderness out of proportion to exam. What would you like to do next?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: - “After 2L crystalloid, his BP improves to 95/55. Labs show WBC 28,000/µL, creatinine 2.8 mg/dL, lactate 6.8 mmol/L. What is your next step?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays operative source control
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Over the next hour, the patient becomes more hypotensive (BP 70/40) despite fluids and requires norepinephrine. What is your management plan now?”
- “You take him to the OR urgently. What is your operative plan?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident describes wide surgical debridement
dynamic_flow.reply: - “On incision, foul-smelling ‘dishwater’ fluid drains, with gray necrotic fascia and noncontractile muscle. How do you proceed?”
- “You debride extensively until healthy bleeding tissue is seen. The wound is left open with temporary dressings. What is your plan for postoperative management?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident fails to mention ICU care and re-exploration
dynamic_flow.reply: - “The patient remains intubated and on vasopressors in the ICU. What additional measures will you order for his postoperative care?”
- “You return him to the OR 24 hours later. Residual necrosis is found and further debridement is performed. What reconstructive considerations might arise once infection is controlled?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proposes amputation for uncontrolled disease
dynamic_flow.reply: - “Despite repeated debridements, the infection continues to spread proximally into the pelvis. What would you do now?”

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays amputation in unstable setting
dynamic_flow.reply: - “The patient arrests intraoperatively from refractory septic shock. Resuscitation efforts are unsuccessful.”
- “You proceed with hip disarticulation. The patient survives and gradually improves with ongoing ICU support and wound care. What is your long-term plan for rehabilitation and infection monitoring?”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of necrotizing infection as a surgical emergency
Appropriate early resuscitation and empiric antibiotics
Adequacy of surgical source control (wide debridement, possible amputation)
Postoperative critical care and repeated explorations
Recognition of reconstructive needs after infection control
